author: Andy Anderson
bottom_line: Hot sunny weather will likely cause wet snow avalanches and cornice failures today. Some places may not have refrozen last night, and in those that did, the change from semi-frozen snow to wet mush will happen fast. Once the snow becomes unsupportable or wet snow gets more than a few inches deep this morning, it’s time to move away from slopes steep enough to produce avalanches.
hazard_discussion:
• Observers reported widespread wet loose avalanches, large pinwheels, and rollerballs starting around 10 am yesterday all across the forecast area. 
  • Recent new snow may have assimilated with the older melt-freeze crust below it on E-SE-S-SW-W aspects in areas that received three inches or less of new snowfall on Friday. Areas that were wind-loaded or received more snow will take longer for the recent new snow to transition to uniform melt-freeze in the upper snowpack.

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion:
Temperatures stayed well above freezing again last night. While the snowpack may have lost enough heat to the clear night sky for a thin, weak refreeze in some areas, other areas may not have refrozen, especially on tree-covered slopes. Today's intense sunshine and warm weather will quickly melt through whatever refreeze did occur and create unstable wet snow on all aspects. Yesterday, a small wet loose avalanche carried the skier who triggered it downhill and almost pushed them into rocks before they stopped. Today's wet snow avalanches could also be large enough to cause problems for backcountry travelers. 

Wet snow avalanches entrain more snow as they slide downhill, so expect larger activity on long steep slopes. Once the snow becomes unsupportable, starts to feel wet, or pinwheels/rollerballs start occurring, wet loose avalanches will follow quickly. You can reduce the risk of encountering wet snow avalanches by recreating on slopes less steep than 35 ° without steeper slopes above. Timing your day to find supportable snow may not work today since whatever refreeze may exist will melt so fast that conditions will change quickly.

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Wet Loose
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Wet Loose avalanches are the release of wet unconsolidated snow or slush. These avalanches typically occur within layers of wet snow near the surface of the snowpack, but they may quickly gouge into lower snowpack layers. Like Loose Dry Avalanches, they start at a point and entrain snow as they move downhill, forming a fan-shaped avalanche. Other names for loose-wet avalanches include point-release avalanches or sluffs. Loose Wet avalanches can trigger slab avalanches that break into deeper snow layers.

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion:
Cornice failures will be likely today as the sun and warm weather weaken the cornices along many ridgelines. Large to massive blocks falling off these overhanging waves of snow could cause problems on their own or trigger wet snow avalanches on the slopes below.

Predicting exactly when a cornice will fail is nearly impossible. Cornice failures almost always surprise the people who trigger them by failing farther away from the edge than expected and failing much larger than expected. Stay well away from cornices by putting exposed rocks or trees between you and the cornice. Consider avoiding travel on slopes below cornices.

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Cornice Fall
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Cornice Fall is the release of an overhanging mass of snow that forms as the wind moves snow over a sharp terrain feature, such as a ridge, and deposits snow on the downwind (leeward) side. Cornices range in size from small wind drifts of soft snow to large overhangs of hard snow that are 30 feet (10 meters) or taller. They can break off the terrain suddenly and pull back onto the ridge top and catch people by surprise even on the flat ground above the slope. Even small cornices can have enough mass to be destructive and deadly. Cornice Fall can entrain loose surface snow or trigger slab avalanches.
